docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Esse projeto serve para agregar materiais de estudos produzidos por mim

Estou utilizando mkdocs para criá-lo

docs.title: Present Perfect & Present Perfect Continuous
docs.text:
We use the present perfect and the present perfect continuous for fineshed and unfinished actions

Have/Has

Present perfect utilize the have/has, so we need to remember when to use then

I have you have he/she/it has we have you have they have Verbs

The present perfect utilize the past participle, this is the third column of the verbs. Go to the Verb Table

docs.title: Formula
docs.text: The "formula" for the sentences are:

docs.title: Present Perfect
docs.text:
Positive 
'have/has' + 'past participle'
Example

I have worked

Negative 
'have/has' + 'not' + 'past participle'
Example

I haven't worked

Question 
'have/has' + 'subject' + 'past participle'
Example

Have I worked

docs.title: Present Perfect Continuous
docs.text:
Positive 
'have/has' + 'been' + 'verb-ing'
Example

I have been working

Negative 
'have/has' + 'not' + 'been' + 'verb-ing'
Example

I have not been working

Question 
'have/has' + 'subject' + 'been' + 'verb-ing'
Example

Have I been working?

We cannot use the present perfect continuous with stative verbs

stative verbs don't refer to a physical action, they express something that is permanent, they express a state or a condition.

To like, to love, to believe, to know, to understand,

exemplo:

I've know her for years.

I've been knowing her for years

I've been here for a while

I've been being here for a while

We can use the two for unfinished actions that started in the past and are still true now

generaly we use with since and for

like:

I have lived in England for 3 years I have been studying English since 2003

the present perfect continuous can be used to emphasise the amount or length of time that has passed, whereas the present perfect is generally neutral

she has been working for hours!

she has worked for hours.

Present perfect is commonly used to talk about how much or how many

she has eaten three pieces of toast this morning

she has been eating 3 pieces of toast this morning.

He's drunk 7 cups of coffee this morning.

He's been drinking 7 cups of coffe this morning.

The present perfect continuous often focuses on the action itself, whereas the present perfect focuses on the completition of the action.

I've been watching the TV series you recommended

been watching: I'm still watching it.

I've watched the TV series you recommended.

watched: I have finished watching it

with the present perfect we can use YET and ALREADY

-- already vai no final ou no começo I've seen the film already

I've already seen the film

-- yet vai no final Have you seen the film yet?

No, I haven't seen it yet

We can use the present perfect continuous to talk about situations that aren't permanent. Things that are not usual.

I've been sleeping badly

Normally I buy lunch at the canteen, but I have been bringing lunch from home.

docs.title: Bloco de código
docs.text:
meu_arquivo.py
def xpto():
"""Docstring."""
return True

def xpto():
"""Docstring."""
   return True

select * from table_x

function x(a){
console.log('abc')
}

print('abc')
>>> abc

docs.title: Fixtures
docs.text: Fixtures are funcions that are run by pytest before (and sometimes after) the actual test functions. The code in the fixture can do watver you want it to.
